contentrichtext.text: In [[New Zealand]], '''native schools''' were established to provide [[education]] for [[Māori people|Māori]]. Until the 1860s, the government [[subsidy|subsidised]] [[church school]]s for Māori. Early [[missionary]] schools were often conducted in the [[Māori language]], which was the predominant language throughout the early part of the 19th century. By the 1860s, three-quarters of the Māori population could read in Māori and two-thirds could write in Māori. The Education Ordinance of 1847 provided funding for mission schools and required them to conduct classes in [[English language|English]] in order to receive subsidies. The [[New Zealand Wars]] however forced the closing of most of the mission schools.<ref>[http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/matauranga-maori-education/page-2 "Missionaries and the early colonial period"], TeAra.govt.nz</ref> The Native Schools Act of 1867 was a major shift in policy. Rather than helping churches to rebuild mission schools after the wars, the government offered secular, state-controlled, primary schools to Māori communities who petitioned for them. In return for providing a suitable site, the government provided a school, teacher, books, and materials.<ref> [http://www.waitangi-tribunal.govt.nz/reports/viewchapter.asp?reportID=D5D84302-EB22-4A52-BE78-16AF39F71D91&chapter=132|Waitangi Tribunal Report on Ngai Tahu Schools and Hospitals] </ref> The act required that English be the only language used in the education of Māori children,<ref>[http://www.tetaurawhiri.govt.nz/english/issues_e/hist/index.shtml Māori Language Issues - Te Taura Whiri i te Reo Māori - Māori Language Commission<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> and Māori were generally strongly supportive of their children learning English as they saw benefits in being able to work with Pākehā.<ref>[http://www.archives.govt.nz/exhibitions/pastexhibitions/tereo/1840_eng.php Archives New Zealand<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> [[James Henry Pope]] (1837–1913) was appointed the organising inspector of native schools in January 1880 and he issued a Native Schools Code later in 1880 that prescribed a curriculum, established qualifications for teachers, and standardised operation for the native schools. The primary mission was to [[Assimilation (sociology)|assimilate]] Māori into European culture. Māori could attend board of education schools and non-Māori could attend native Schools, although the primary purpose of the Native Schools was providing European education for Māori. Throughout the 20th century the number of Native schools decreased and Māori increasingly attended board of education schools. The native schools remained distinct from other New Zealand schools until 1969, when the last 108 native schools were transferred to the control of education boards.<ref>[http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/matauranga-maori-education/page-3 "The native schools system, 1867 to 1969"], TeAra.govt.nz</ref> ==See also== * [[History of education in New Zealand]] * [[Native American boarding schools]] in the United States * [[Canadian Indian residential school system|Residential schools in Canada]] * [[Cultural genocide]] ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.archives.govt.nz/exhibitions/tereo/index_eng.html Māori Language in State Education] from the Archives New Zealand{{dead link|date=February 2013}} * [http://www.waitangi-tribunal.govt.nz/scripts/reports/reports/718/75BF64FC-B0AD-47EE-ADC6-5CF7C764BD0B.pdf Māori Education in New Zealand: A Historical Overview] Chapter 2 of a [[Waitangi Tribunal]] Report {{Schools}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Native Schools}} [[Category:Cultural assimilation]] [[Category:Māori history]] [[Category:Māori organisations]] [[Category:Māori language]] [[Category:Minority schools]] [[Category:History of education in New Zealand]]
